item.title: Trump’s ‘Fire and Fury’ Threat Raises Alarm in Asia
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers last week in Panmunjom, a village that straddles the border with North Korea.
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: While some officials played down the president’s warning to North Korea, some analysts said that the escalating rhetoric increased the likelihood of war.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: On North Korea Threat, ‘Americans Should Sleep Well at Night,’ Tillerson Says
item.media:description: Secretary of State Rex Tillerson arriving in Malaysia on Tuesday. During his trip back to Washington on Wednesday, Mr. Tillerson said that despite an exchange of threats, there was no imminent threat from North Korea.
item.media:credit: Lai Seng Sin/Reuters
item.description: Despite recent exchanges between North Korea and President Trump, the secretary of state says Americans should not be concerned about threats from the country.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and EILEEN SULLIVAN

item.title: Trump Threatens North Korea With ‘Fire and Fury’
item.description: “North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States,” President Trump said after the isolated nuclear-armed country criticized the United States earlier in the day.

item.title: Trump’s Harsh Language on North Korea Has Little Precedent, Experts Say
item.description: The statement went far beyond the usual tough-but-vague words that past presidents have used to confront the North’s frequent provocations.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Answers to 4 Crucial Questions About North Korea
item.media:description: Portraits of Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il, the first two leaders of North Korea, in Pyongyang, the capital. Intelligence suggests the country has nuclear weapons small enough for an intercontinental missile.
item.media:credit: Ed Jones/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Keeping track of all of the weapons tests, sanctions and diplomatic efforts can be dizzying. Here’s a rundown of the standoff.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: North Korea’s Potential Targets: Guam, South Korea and Japan
item.media:description: An Applebee’s in Tamuning, Guam. Though Guam, an American territory, is used to threats from North Korea, several residents said the current situation felt more dangerous.
item.media:credit: Nancy Borowick for The New York Times
item.description: Pyongyang has the capability to launch a devastating military attack on Seoul, and its leader has missiles could hit Tokyo and perhaps Guam.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Climate Report Could Force Trump to Choose Between Science and His Base
item.media:description: President Trump at a meeting on Tuesday at the Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: The looming publication of a climate report again raises a contentious policy issue that has deeply divided President Trump’s closest advisers since he arrived in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and BRAD PLUMER
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: North Korea, Paris, David Letterman: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: The U.S. naval base at Apra Harbor, Guam, in 2016. North Korea has warned that it is considering a strike that would create “an enveloping fire” around the western Pacific island.
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Landis/Department of Defense, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: A Movie to Unite Us?
item.media:description: We doubt this will do it.
item.media:credit: MGM
item.description: New York Today: Readers weigh in on New York City films, picture-perfect weather, and the 35th anniversary of the Gay Men’s Health Crisis.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WOLFE

item.title: In the Age of Trump, the Dollar No Longer Seems a Sure Thing
item.media:description: Since early January, the dollar has lost more than 6 percent compared with the Japanese yen.
item.media:credit: Yuya Shino/Getty Images
item.description: Long the ultimate safe haven in the global economy, the U.S. dollar may be losing some status as investors grapple with an uncertain political climate.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Even on Break, a Congress Weary of Trump Gets No Respite From Him
item.media:description: Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, arrived at the Capitol last week for a final vote before August recess.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: So much for relaxing. The president is in meetings and taking calls, he said on Twitter, keeping the capital on edge when it badly needs a breather.
item.dc:creator: MATT FLEGENHEIMER

item.title: Vowing Again to Tackle Opioid Crisis, Trump Faults His Predecessor
item.media:description: President Trump spoke with top advisers at a meeting on the opioid crisis at his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., on Tuesday. From right, the first lady, Melania Trump; Mr. Trump; Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services; and Kellyanne Conway, the presidential counselor.
item.media:credit: Al drago for The New York Times
item.description: The president met with top advisers at his New Jersey golf club to discuss the drug overdose problem, but offered no specific initiatives to stem the tide.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

item.title: The Sea Level Did, in Fact, Rise Faster in the Southeast U.S.
item.media:description: Flooding in Charleston, S.C., last summer. From 2011 to 2015, the sea level along the southeastern American coastline rose six times faster than the long-term rate of global increase.
item.media:credit: Hunter McRae for The New York Times
item.description: Scientists may have found the culprit of sudden tidal flooding: Two atmospheric patterns that combined to cause fast-rising waters along the coast.
item.dc:creator: JUSTIN GILLIS

item.title: The Culture Wars Have Come to Silicon Valley
item.media:description: Peter Thiel, left, and Reed Hastings. Mr. Thiel, a member of Facebook’s board of directors, was told by Mr. Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, that he would receive a negative evaluation of his performance on the board because of his support for Donald J. Trump.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Andy Chen/The New York Times. Photos by Andrew White for The New York Times; Justin Sullivan, via Getty Images
item.description: After Google fired an engineer who wrote an anti-diversity manifesto, the tech industry is under the microscope for penalizing dissenting opinions.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Contentious Memo Strikes Nerve Inside Google and Out
item.media:description: Google has faced many questions about the number of women employed there as engineers and managers.
item.media:credit: Jeff Chiu/Associated Press
item.description: The memo, written by a Google engineer who was later fired, enraged diversity advocates and also served as a rallying cry for conservatives and the alt-right.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: As Investigations Intensify, Israel Imagines Life After Netanyahu
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu arriving at a cabinet meeting last month. Mr. Netanyahu has dominated the Israeli political scene for years.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Abir Sultan
item.description: As an ex-aide turns state’s witness, Israelis across the spectrum are trying on the idea of the curtain coming down on Mr. Netanyahu’s career.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Car Slams Into Soldiers in Paris Suburb, Injuring Six
item.media:description: Police officers and soldiers at the scene in Levallois-Perret, a suburb of Paris, where a car rammed into six soldiers on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Benoit Tessier/Reuters
item.description: The soldiers were wounded while on patrol when a BMW hit them in Levallois-Perret. The mayor of the town called it a “despicable aggression.”
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: South America’s Street Art Mecca
item.description: Join a graffiti tour on a trip through Bogotá, where the form has evolved into a mixture of social commentary, cultural expression and art.

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: Feature: What a Fraternity Hazing Death Revealed About the Painful Search for an Asian-American Identity
item.media:credit: Jamie Chung for The New York Times
item.description: When Michael Deng, a college freshman, joined an Asian-American fraternity, he was looking for a sense of belonging and identity. Two months later he was dead.
item.dc:creator: JAY CASPIAN KANG

item.title: Glen Campbell, Whose Hit Songs Bridged Country and Pop, Dies at 81
item.media:description: Glen Campbell playing guitar as host of the NBC television show “The Midnight Special” in 1975.
item.media:credit: NBC, via Getty Images
item.description: A sharecropper’s son who became a recording, television and movie star, Mr. Campbell also battled alcohol and drugs and became a public face of Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POLLAK
item.category: By the Time I Get to Phoenix (Song)

item.title: Ole Miss Edges Out of Its Confederate Shadow, Gingerly
item.media:description: The Lucius Q.C. Lamar House Museum in Oxford, Miss. At Ole Miss, a plaque will be added at Lamar Hall describing his slaveholding and opposition to Reconstruction.
item.media:credit: Timothy Ivy for The New York Times
item.description: At Ole Miss, where even an architect of disenfranchisement still has his name on a building, the process of addressing the past is more sensitive than at most universities.
item.dc:creator: STEPHANIE SAUL

item.title: Russia Wants Innovation, but It’s Arresting Its Innovators
item.media:description: Dmitri Verkhoved, a mathematician who was director of the technopark in Akademgorodok, a Russian town that is a Soviet-era sanctuary of scientific research.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The detention of a Siberian scientist turned high-tech entrepreneur stirs dismay as Russia struggles to diversify its faltering economy beyond oil and gas.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Bill Murray Relives a Role, Seeing Broadway’s ‘Groundhog Day’
item.media:description: Bill Murray at the bar on Tuesday night at “Groundhog Day,” the Broadway musical based on the film in which he starred. He was attending the show for the first time.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Murray attended the musical for the first time on Tuesday night, and the performance brought him to tears.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB

item.title: Chasing Shadows for a Glimpse of a Tiny World Beyond Pluto
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of one possible version of the Kuiper belt object 2014 MU69, the next flyby target for NASA’s New Horizons mission.
item.media:credit: Alex Parker/NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory/Southwest Research Institute
item.description: From just five blinks of starlight, scientists now know more about the next destination of NASA’s New Horizons spacecraft.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Kenya Election Returns Were Hacked, Opposition Leader Says
item.media:description: Riot police officers were deployed in the Mathare area of Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday to disperse supporters of the opposition leader, Raila Odinga, who denounced the presidential election as “a fraud.”
item.media:credit: Thomas Mukoya/Reuters
item.description: Raila Odinga said preliminary results that put him behind the incumbent, Uhuru Kenyatta, were a fraud. At least one person was reported killed in protests.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Missouri Man Arrested in Fatal Shooting of Police Officer
item.media:description: Ian McCarthy, 39, the man suspected of killing a Missouri State Highway Patrol officer in Clinton, Mo., on Sunday night.
item.media:credit: Missouri State Highway Patrol, via Associated Press
item.description: The suspect, Ian McCarthy, was taken into custody on Tuesday night after the authorities received a call about a man walking down a rural road in Urich, Mo.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Mike Duggan and Coleman Young Will Face Off in Detroit’s Mayoral Election
item.media:description: Coleman A. Young II campaigning last month at Clique, a local diner in Detroit, for the coming mayoral race. Mr. Young, 34, a state senator, is the son of Detroit’s first black mayor.
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Duggan, the incumbent mayor, was far ahead among eight candidates, and Mr. Young, the son of Detroit’s longest serving mayor, was a distant second.
item.dc:creator: MONICA DAVEY

item.title: Icy, Sweet and Instagram-Ready
item.description: Ingenious takes on soft serve, shaved ice and other treats from Thailand, Japan and South Korea are putting the American scoop shop to shame.
item.dc:creator: JULIA MOSKIN
item.category: Okamoto Kitchen (Los Angeles, CA, food truck)

item.title: How Rebecca Solnit Became the Voice of the Resistance
item.media:description: Rebecca Solnit, the essayist-turned-progressive-icon, at home in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Trent Davis Bailey
item.description: In recent years, the writer has amassed a new audience — a younger, mostly female group.
item.dc:creator: ALICE GREGORY

item.title: Disney’s Challenge: Keeping It ‘Frozen,’ but Still Fresh
item.media:description: From far left, Cassie Levy, who plays Elsa, and Patti Murin, who plays her sister Anna, in Disney’s stage adaptation of “Frozen”; and the sisters in the 2013 animated film.
item.media:credit: Morgan Rachel Levy for The New York Times. Disney.
item.description: This musical juggernaut is going from the big screen to Broadway. But first, a test run in Denver.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON
item.category: Denver Center for the Performing Arts
